data.title: Key binding and context menu selectors can't cross the shadow DOM
data.body: This is because `Element.matches` doesn't handle `::shadow` selectors properly. We could should probably add a special case to support them because the ability to target specific grammar scopes is an important feature.

data.title: Atom should attempt to reinstall incompatible packages when node is upgraded
data.body: After upgrading node, any packages that have native module dependencies become incompatible. The incompatible packages view offers 3 options: Check for Update, Report Issue and Disable Package. But often the only thing that the package needs is for its modules to be recompiled against the new version. The user is stuck with a package that can't be used until they manually uninstall and reinstall it. Atom should attempt to reinstall these packages, and only consider them incompatible if the reinstall fails.

data.title: "Style sheet" is two words – Treat it that way in the API
data.body:
According to the W3C, ["style sheet" is two words](http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/present/styles.html).

I already updated some of the API to treat it that way a few weeks ago, but I forgot about the package directory layout and the `package.json` keys. This finishes the job. I opted for a one-word directory name, `styles`. The `package.json` keys use camel case.
- Package directory format:
  - `stylesheets/` => `styles/`
- Package metadata:
  - `stylesheets` => `styleSheets`
  - `stylesheetMain` => `mainStyleSheet`

This will unfortunately require another mindless upgrade pass after the next release. I will happily do it though to have correct grammar in our APIs.

data.title: Add Screenshot support to Markdown editing
data.body:
One of the best features of the GitHub Issues UI (the one I'm currently writing on),  is the fact that I can just copy and paste images,  from the clipboard directly into an issue body.

It would be great if (when editing an Markdown file, as shown below) I could also just copy an paste an image. With the workflow being the same as now with the web UI:
- user takes screenshot locally
- user copy and paste into isue
- message 'uploading' is shown for a couple secs
- when upload is complete, the 'uploading' message is replaced with the actually Markdown image URL (as uploaded to the cloud.githubusercontent.com server)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/656739/5680245/8399c204-9802-11e4-8227-6c6f0514008e.png)

data.title: Editor Removes Whitespace Unneccessarily
data.body:
I recognize that extra whitespace is rather unfortunate, but I have to question Atom's solution.  As of right now, the editor removes all unnecessary whitespace like spaces at the ends of lines and spaces on lines without any other content.  However, as I have contributed to several projects, I've gotten questions from the owners of the projects in my Pull requests as to why I unnecessarily adjusted the whitespace. I have to explain that it was my editor.  

Personally, I understand that code should be clean without these things, but owners can seem somewhat agitated with little whitespace changes alongside the fixes for the actual issue at hand.  I feel like there should at least be some way to disable this.

Package class isn't documented, but linked from other documentation
Do not deserialize files that do not exist or we do not have permission to
data.body:
Steps to reproduce
1. Open file1 in atom
2. Open file2 in atom
3. Close atom
4. Remove file1
5. `chmod 000 file2`
6. Open atom to the dir of file2
7. Broken

these 2 cases should be fixed
- When the file doesnt exist anymore, an empty tab is created
- When the user does not have permissions, it fails hard with a big scary `unable to watch path` stack trace

data.title: *HUGE* memory leak
data.body: I just tested .168 and .169 and there is a huge memory leak. I can't tell when exactly this started happening, but around .150 I don't recall seeing this. What is the memory leak about? When I launch Atom, it starts using 20% of my CPU (around 80% of 1 core) and keeps taking RAM until it hits 3GB, and then it stop taking RAM but it keeps using 20% of my CPU. How I reproduce it? I'm unable to reproduce the bug with `atom --safe`. Anyways, I am able to reproduce the bug after completely removing `~/.atom` and then running `atom`, so this bug isn't caused by an external plugin or skin, but by some Atom plugin that isn't loaded with `--safe`. What OS? I'm on Arch Linux x64, everything is up to date. KDE desktop with KWin as WM. NVidia proprietary driver. Atom was installed via AUR.

data.title: Address issues with PackageManager
data.body:
Package manager wasn't invoking `::onDidActivateAll` listeners at the appropriate time. This PR fixes that issue and updates several method names in `PackageManager` and `ThemeManager` for clarity and consistency.
- `PackageManager`
  - `onDidActivateAll` => `onDidActivateInitialPackages`
  - `onDidLoadAll` => `onDidLoadInitialPackages`
- `ThemeManager`
  - `onDidReloadAll` => `onDidChangeActiveThemes`
  - `getActiveNames` => `getActiveThemeNames`
  - `getLoadedNames` => `getLoadedThemeNames`
  - `setEnabledThemes` => deprecated, use `config.set`

data.title: Periodically check for available updates
data.body:
Could we get an indicator when there's an update available for Atom, in addition to the file menu?  If someone leaves Atom open for days at a time, they could easily end up several versions behind.

I'm picturing something like Chrome's indicator, where the hamburger icon goes from green->yellow->red depending on how stale the user's version is.  Maybe just a little light in the status bar.
